16.59.text:
(Chris) I wear this body with pride and 
I'm not phased by what my body looks like now.

28.66.text:
I've built a backup to what I use to be 
and what I like to present.

38.68.text:
(Bridie) I was given the option to have plastic 
surgery to remove my scars at 18.

43.94.text:
Instead I went on a trip around the world and 
did climb the Eiffel Tower.

48.39.text:
And to me that's what I want to do with 
my legs, and that's what they are to me.

55.89.text:
I don't have to like them. Some people don't 
like their hair, or their facial features.

61.69.text:
It's about accepting your body as it is, and being 
happy with yourself every time you look in the mirror.

67.25.text:
And when I look in the mirror I don't see 
what's wrong with me.

69.57.text:
I look in the mirror and I go...
Did I train today hard enough?

77.47.text:
I'll happily be out there with my shirt off, 
or in short shorts having a swim.

82.22.text:
It doesn't really phase me that much anymore.
And I guess people see that and go...

85.85.text:
Oh well if he can deal with that then there are things
in my life I can probably deal with better.

103.51.text:
Chris Bond and Bridie Kean have 
much in common.

107.11.text:
Both amputees, both Paralympians 
and fiercely competitive.

112.49.text: But that's not what they see in each other.

119.74.text:
(Bridie) Are you ready for training already?
(Chris) Yep what are you having for breakfast.

125.29.text:
(Chris) When I first met Bridie, 
she was Captain of the Gliders.

128.94.text:
We actually left in a lift in London. And I 
didn't know many other athletes.

132.92.text:
And we just said hello in passing, and 
didn't think much of it.

136.50.text:
We had bigger focuses in London 
other than our love lives.

141.34.text:
And when we retured, we went to the 'Welcome Home 
Parade,' and we were the last couple of people there.

147.74.text:
And we thought let's go for a drink 
and we got to know each other a little bit.

151.63.text:
And we respected each other as athletes and 
what we'd achieved in London.

155.48.text:
We had a lot in common from day to day life 
to moving interstate for our sport...

161.24.text:
to then potentially moving overseas 
to play our sport.

166.18.text: And something about Bridie intrigued me.

171.85.text:
(Bridie) I remember when I met Chris, one 
thing that intrigued me about him was...

176.40.text:
that I saw him wearing shorts and that 
he had similar scars to me.

180.09.text:
I'm not saying that it's a drawcard 
or anything.

187.63.text:
But we do have a similar life philosophy and 
sometimes that gets us in trouble.

192.45.text:
Because we spur each other on, when if
one of us had less expectations of life...

199.56.text:
then we would calm down a bit. Instead there's 
this constant drive to do more and never give up.

212.91.text:
Sport has become Chris Bond's life. He took 
up wheelchair rugby three years ago.

219.68.text:
Within a year the Australians were the gold 
medalists at the London Paralympics.

228.57.text: Their funding depends on staying at the top.

237.19.text:
In a wheelchair, Chris can do almost anything 
but he was never content to stay there.

245.67.text:
It took him a year of rehab to learn 
to walk again.

248.84.text:
After complications from cancer cost him 
his lower limbs and most of his hands.

255.64.text:
(Chris) In the beginning it's very painful. The human 
body is not made to bear weight on your knees.

261.25.text:
And it takes a lot of adjusting for your skin and the 
pressure to be able to do it semi comfortably.

268.38.text:
If you have heat issues it's a struggle because 
they are silicon liners and trap heat...

273.67.text: so it's quite uncomfortable in the sun.

278.09.text:
When I first started it was tiring, like I 
wasn't as fit as I am now.

281.99.text:
It's like being a baby again and learning how 
to walk, it's not the same.

285.70.text:
It's a lot of one step forward, 
and two steps backwards.

297.22.text:
But now it's just how I live my life and 
I don't know any different anymore.

304.17.text:
Usually someone with an amputation 
has scars or fragile skin.

309.53.text:
So I probably couldn't walk 
all day, everyday.

314.36.text:
But the body does heal and it does adapt very well. 
Eventually most people will regain...

320.77.text: the ability to walk, if they've had amputations, on prosthesis.

333.56.text:
There are times when it would be easier 
to stay in a wheelchair...

337.29.text:
and not learn to wear prosthetics and 
get out and do things for yourself.

343.74.text:
I've had a purpose built unit built on 
my house back in Canberra.

348.87.text:
So, I could still be there with my mum making 
meals and washing my clothes if I wanted too.

353.59.text:
And that might be an easy life, but it doesn't have 
the satisfaction of going out there...

360.19.text:
and challenging yourself, and making your 
own goals, starting your own life...

365.84.text:
your own passions, and being who 
you want to be.

372.87.text:
Chris and his twin brother grew 
up loving sport.

377.52.text:
At 19, he was in his first job as a trainee chef, 
and playing weekend leauge.

387.47.text:
Overnight he was laid out by what seemed 
like a 24-hour gastric bug.

392.72.text: No one was prepared for what was to come.

396.41.text:
(Chris) All I can remember is that they said that 
there's something definitely wrong with you.

401.08.text:
And we're going to have to operate, open you up, 
look inside and see what's going on.

409.61.text: That diagnoses had only just been delivered...

412.64.text:
when Chris developed Septicemia -
blood poisoning.

424.24.text:
(Chris) "Because of the rate that it's going you may
only have a 50% chance to survive this operation."

431.52.text:
"So say goodbye to your family." 
That's a hard thing at 19 years old.

438.91.text: I got about ten seconds with my mum.

441.71.text:
She said, "I'll see you when you get out, just be strong," 
and then they wheeled me away.

452.26.text:
I went into depression at that stage, 
pretty heavily and quickly

459.49.text:
It took a while to get my head around 
what had happened...

462.70.text:
and I couldn't stop asking myself why 
this happened to me.

467.64.text:
I've always had a sense that there are things
I need to achieve yet before I'm done...

472.63.text:
which pushed me out of feeling sorry 
for myself into an active mode...

478.28.text:
of wanting to contribute back in ways, 
maybe to the community...

485.23.text:
or to other people who have had disability and 
gone through what I've been through.

488.71.text: Chris spent a year battling the Leukemia.

491.48.text:
Rounds of chemotherapy, therapy 
and recovery.

496.64.text:
Finally well, it was sport that opened up 
a new world for him.

510.14.text:
In the nine years since his amputations, 
Chris has completely remodeled his body.

521.55.text:
(Chris) I need to be strong because my arms 
are my legs in some regard.

527.83.text:
It's just a part of being in a chair but 
then also being an athlete...

531.58.text:
I do a lot of upper work being a 
wheelchair athlete.

534.95.text:
So, it pays off and why not reap the 
rewards of it and embrace it.

541.45.text:
Chris started to swim competitively, 
yet he needed more.

545.87.text:
He found it when a coach for wheelchair
rugby saw his strength.

554.77.text:
(Chris) At the camp he got me in a chair, and 
there were a few others guys on court...

558.26.text:
and he said, "You see that guy other there?" He said, 
"Push up to him and hit him as hard as you can.

563.32.text:
I was like, "Hang on is this part of the rules? 
Is this for real?"

565.97.text: And he said, "Yeah go and have a go."

568.09.text:
So I did, pushed up and smashed into him. 
And ever since then I just loved it.

573.84.text:
I love the impact, the contact, 
the raw nature of rugby.

580.91.text:
Three years ago, Chris joined the 
National Team.

584.18.text:
And his talent saw him selected for 
the Paralympics in London.

588.79.text: (Chris) I've always been a fit, athletic guy.

591.24.text:
So, it's good to get out there and still 
play sport and be athletic.

597.35.text:
We like to push ourselves to the limit and 
see what these bodies can do.

601.22.text:
And there's nothing much that stops 
me in my own life.

604.03.text:
And I believe Bridie probably 
thinks that way too.

606.50.text:
In our sports we are the highest 
functioning players in our teams.

609.90.text:
So, we are sort of able bodied anyway in 
relation to our other team mates.

613.92.text:
They see us as able bodied because we do 
everything most people standing up would do.

618.44.text: So, I think that's just how I see us and myself.

630.16.text: Bridie trains at the same gym.

633.07.text:
She has had years to adjust to 
her amputations.

637.43.text:
(Bridie) When I was two years old, 
I became quite sick.

641.34.text:
And my mum knew something was wrong 
because it presented with flu-like symptoms.

646.63.text:
But after a couple of days she took me to a local doctor 
who saw that a rash was starting to cover my body.

655.82.text:
A lumbar puncture confirmed that I had 
Meningococcal Septicemia.

659.83.text:
At this point I was extremely sick, 
and they were told that I had 12 hours that 
would determine whether I would live or die.

669.35.text:
I started to get better, however the rash had 
turned my extremities gangrenous.

675.75.text:
And following that they were informed that I would 
have to have those parts of my legs amputated.

683.42.text: So, I had a series of operations growing up.

687.35.text:
As a child I tried to play able bodied sport. 
I was able to walk and run with a little pain.

694.58.text: And then when I was 15, I discovered wheelchair basketball.

701.08.text:
She's now the Captain of the
Australian Wheelchair Basketball Team, the Gliders.

705.93.text: Silver medalists from the London Paralympics.

710.16.text:
It's clear to me now that when I play sport, 
I focus on what I can do, not what I can't do.

720.56.text:
Even as a female and going to 
an all-girls school...

723.41.text:
where there is so much pressure now to 
have your body look a certain way.

729.86.text:
For me, exercise and sport makes me think about 
my body in terms of function and what it can do.

736.75.text:
And when I'm lifting weights I'm thinking... I want to 
be strong, not skinny and look like something 
I'm never going to look like.

764.14.text: As a couple they have so much in common.

767.39.text:
But they're fiercely competitive as well, 
even on the small points.

772.05.text:
(Bridie) Neither of us want to lose because 
we're drilled to want to win.

777.96.text:
And it leads to competitions sometimes over 
small things, but it's always in good fun.

783.28.text:
We've acknowledged that Bridie's better at 
wheelchair basketball and I'm better at wheelchair rugby.

788.56.text:
(Bridie) And the rest is up for grabs.
(Chris) We're still working those other things out.

793.26.text: Things like how long they've been together.

798.16.text: (Bridie) Maybe seven months, two days and three hours. No I'm just kidding.

801.02.text:
(Chris) I think it's about five or six months.
(Bridie) No it's definitely over six.

803.61.text:
(Chris) There you go.
(Bridie) September, no I think it was August.

809.06.text:
(Bridie) It's been a bit of a blur.
(Chris) I'll give that one to you, I don't know.

812.12.text:
(Chris) Bridie invited herself over for dinner.
(Bridie) (Laughs) A dinner date.

815.93.text:
(Chris) And somehow I was making roast lamb 
that night, so I came off looking pretty good.

819.45.text: (Bridie) I was on the way to work, so I was stuck in traffic...

822.62.text: (Chris) That's quite a way around to get there...

825.45.text:
(Bridie) But he didn't know Brisbane that 
well so he didn't figure it out.

828.06.text: (Chris) We're both pretty new to Brisbane.

830.74.text:
(Chris) We had a lot in common and we just 
found a friendship and comfort in the fact...

834.49.text:
that we're both on this journey alone 
in this State together.

837.87.text: I guess we just fell in love and it sort of works.

856.11.text:
Beyond sport, Chris and Bridie give their time 
to causes that reflect their values.

861.63.text:
After years of being involved in Canteen, 
the teen cancer charity...

865.90.text:
Chris was asked to take part in a fundraiser for 
young adult cancer survivors.

875.64.text:
(Photographer) Hey how are you?
(Chris) Gidday how're you going?

881.44.text:
(Chris) I dragged Bridie into doing it with me. 
And we decided that we wanted to embrace the idea.

886.20.text:
And we got down to our underwear to show that 
we are not scared to reveal ourselves...

892.87.text:
and that every scar tells a story. And that we should 
embrace the scars that we have.

902.95.text:
(Chris) Having never done anything like this 
before we didn't know what to expect.

907.66.text:
So, it took a lot for us to reveal ourselves with 
not wearing not much at all.

912.77.text: But we had fun with it and it turned out well.

919.73.text: (Chris) Yeah it just seems very comical to me that photo.

922.66.text:
I guess, looking at it in an artistic way 
I might be able to appreciate it.

929.84.text:
But, just us, and me at her butt. We had some jokes 
about it... her farting on me.

934.28.text:
(Photographer) There she is, beautiful.
(Chris) I like that photo, yeah.

937.17.text: (Chris) I like that one in color, it's really warm.

941.78.text:
While they make everything look easy... 
Chris and Bridie acknowledge that's not always the case.

949.51.text:
(Bridie) I probably look like I always have a lot of 
energy and want to run around and do a lot.

953.68.text:
And then, Chris is probably one of the 
few people that I trust enough...

957.90.text: to be around and say, "This is hard today."

962.69.text:
You roll with those days, and we face them together 
I would like to think. And then we move on.

969.51.text:
(Chris) We're looked up to as elite athletes 
and as role models.

974.16.text:
I guess, we try and be positive and upbeat 
as much as possible.

977.05.text:
But in the comfort of our own home we 
open up to each other and share our thoughts...

981.27.text:
about maybe being upset about things, or 
if we're having a bad day.

984.50.text:
But to be honest, 80% is not about disability.
It's just everyday problems.

996.54.text:
Today, just a review on my new legs.
I want to check how they are going.

1000.70.text:
And maybe some advice on adjustments 
that might make it a little easier.

1007.84.text:
(Chris) Pretty good. 
I had a wedding last weekend...

1011.36.text:
and I was on them for about five to six hours 
straight because I had pants on...

1016.54.text:
and I felt a little sore afterwards, but I think 
that's going to happen anyway.

1019.69.text:
(Prosthetist) Shall we have a look at it then?
(Chris) Yep.

1023.00.text:
(Prosthetist) We'll often get him to come in and he'll say, 
"I've been dancing all night on the limbs at a night club and...

1028.85.text:
out until about 3am, and I've got 
a bit of a problem with the legs."

1033.33.text:
And we'll get a call in the morning, 
and he'll have to come in and see us.

1036.37.text:
But that's why we do this job. We don't want 
to make a prostheses that's never used.

1042.55.text:
(Prosthetist) Walk up and down and 
we'll see how it looks.

1054.96.text:
Not much different with that extra sock on now, 
but I could see how it would help later on.

1061.39.text:
(Prosthetist) You can imagine for someone like Chris, 
just for him to go for a normal walk for 100 meters...

1065.47.text:
he's using 50% more energy than you and 
I would be just walking normally.

1070.80.text:
So, you can understand when you weight that 
up against being in a wheelchair...

1074.87.text:
that it just makes sense for them to 
use the wheelchair.

1077.45.text:
But someone like Chris, he won't accept that and 
he'll do anything to keep his mobility.

1099.61.text:
Chris trains five days a week.
He treats it as his job right now.

1104.91.text: And the Australian Team is riding high as the gold medalists at the Paralympics.

1110.28.text:
Their next challenge will be the Canada Cup, 
a ten nation tournament.

1117.58.text:
(Chris) There are a lot of different ways 
you can approach a game.

1121.03.text: And it does depend on who you are playing.

1124.20.text: My role, I'm a 3.5 player, so I'm a ball carrier.

1127.67.text:
My job is to take control of the team on court and 
get that ball in my hands and score goals.

1134.26.text:
And in defense to be defending any player 
or two players at once.

1142.07.text:
International opportunities are there for 
those at the top of the game.

1146.31.text:
Chris has been headhunted for the 
Texas State Team.

1150.72.text:
(Chris) The American Leauge in wheelchair rugby 
is the strongest leauge in the world.

1154.32.text: So, a lot of players get headhunted to play.

1158.05.text:
I was the same, after London, the 
Texas coach lured me in.

1162.57.text:
It can only increase and help develop myself in my 
game being over there with the best players in the world.

1169.26.text:
(Coach) Physically in the gym, pound for pound 
in a normal mainstream gym...

1174.02.text:
he'd be one of the stronger guys there. 
And he's missing half his bits and pieces.

1177.92.text:
So, not only is he strong here (heart), 
he's strong here (mind), but he's also physically strong.

1183.42.text:
So, all of those three - strong heart, strong mind, and strong 
physically - all put him together to be a fantastic package.

1191.73.text:
Texas will be even hotter than Brisbane, 
something Chris struggles with.

1197.99.text:
(Chris) I sweat a lot and my temperature is always 
a lot higher than other people.

1202.40.text:
Because I don't have as much surface area of 
my skin as other people...

1206.66.text:
and then some of the skin I do have is skin grafted, 
which doesn't sweat.

1215.06.text:
While Chris plans his season with the 
Texas State Team...

1218.38.text: Bridie is concentrating on her studies.

1221.67.text:
(Bridie) There are amazing opportunities 
up here at the moment, and I'm working a lot...

1226.16.text:
and hoping to progress my study by concentrating 
on that for six months. So I'm going to relocate up here.

1234.33.text:
There is already a Paralympic Swim 
Program here on campus.

1237.59.text:
And it's a pipe dream, but I would love to see that 
happen for wheelchair basketball and wheelchair rugby.

1244.22.text:
But adapted athletics, because that's the 
environment I had overseas in the U.S.

1248.45.text:
And I think this University offers the same 
freshness and facilities...

1254.93.text:
to provide opportunities both in the 
academics and the sporting field.

1267.95.text:
She's also a tutor at the University, 
as well as doing a PHD.

1273.60.text:
(Bridie) It's a study that is actually going to look 
at physical activity...

1278.09.text:
and what motivates people and what the 
barriers are for people with disabilities.

1283.69.text:
We're going to look at what motivates 
Paralympians. It's very close to home.

1289.20.text:
But what I really like about it is that it's looking 
at the things that drive people to do things.

1295.17.text:
Not what holds people back. 
I want to work in preventative health.

1299.48.text: I think that prevention is the best cure.

1302.55.text:
So, for that exercise is such a healthy way to even 
connect with your own body and focus on what it can do.

1312.56.text:
The fact that I can run now...
it's probably not good for me to run,

1316.85.text:
so I don't do it too often because 
it is hard on my joints.

1320.43.text:
But it's something that as a child I didn't 
think I'd ever be able to do.

1329.40.text:
The Australians are on the road.
The Canada Cup is contested by ten nations.

1335.92.text:
And it's the Canadians who will be 
their toughest competition.

1340.56.text:
More than reputation depends on this match.
Maintaining their funding depends on performance.

1347.12.text:
(Chris) They're one of our big threats going 
into World Championships.

1349.81.text: Mentally, I've gone over some video of Canada.

1352.37.text: We'll talk strategy soon in our team meeting.

1355.41.text:
But we've got to back ourselves, we've beaten 
Canada many times before.

1419.05.text:
(Chris) It was a pretty tough week. 
But we did it in the end...

1422.24.text:
we won the gold medal here at 
the Canada Cup.

1425.54.text:
Tough game again, Canada brought it to us and 
kept us going the whole game.

1430.69.text:
It's great. It sends a message to the world that 
we're still here, and we're still good.

1435.43.text: We don't rest on our laurels from London.

1438.60.text:
We're aiming to win World Champs this year and 
then go onto win back to back gold in Rio.

1464.26.text:
Bridie and Chris are fast approaching 
a separation of distance.

1469.67.text: He will be playing in America for six months.

1472.94.text: And Bridie will relocate to the Sunshine Coast.

1476.82.text:
Opportunities to spend time together 
are precious.

1483.72.text:
(Chris) When we get the chance we like to 
come out and dine outside.

1487.65.text:
And just embrace the gorgeous 
city that we live in.

1492.72.text:
We sacrifice a lot of our social life for our sport, 
so we still have to make the time for friends 
as well up here that we've made.

1504.17.text:
(Bridie) It's nothing like Melbourne, 
which is where I'm from.

1509.13.text:
It's nice to take it all in and make that effort 
to go and sit outside.

1525.39.text:
The Scar Stories book has just 
been launched.

1528.97.text: Chris is at a book signing to promote sales.

1540.11.text:
(Jasmine) Chris has been a really great 
advocate for Scar Stories.

1543.22.text:
As he's been for all the other organizations 
he's worked within the past.

1547.07.text:
Since coming onboard and having his portrait 
taken, he's also our keynote speaker at our book launch.

1553.72.text:
So, we had about 110 people really just 
enthralled by his speech.

1560.17.text:
He spoke with grace and he spoke about
his whole experiece with cancer, with the other
organizations and with our organization.

1572.40.text:
(Chris) There you go, enjoy, all yours. 
Thank you for coming today.

1575.49.text:
(Lady) Thank you.
(Chris) Cheers, nice to meet you.

1578.22.text:
(Chris) For us, life doesn't end... 
a lot of traumatic things have happened 
to myself and Bridie...

1585.27.text:
and it has changed our life, but it 
hasn't changed us as people.

1590.79.text:
When you go out there and show that you 
can still be confident...

1594.25.text:
have character and have a presence 
even though you may look different than 
other people now.

1598.57.text:
You may bear these scars...
and to embrace the scars.

1607.68.text:
(Bridie) Chris is going to Texas and at the same 
time I've got a lot of work to do 
here on campus.

1614.15.text:
Both of us have amazing opportunities 
waiting for us, so we're going to take
them and get each other through them as well.

1625.32.text:
(Chris) When I was 19 years old and 
I got really, really sick...

1628.47.text:
I didn't see much past the week ahead and
didn't want to see past the week ahead 
to be honest.

1635.06.text:
But step by step, and every little milestone, 
and every small goal that I accomplished, 
doors starting opening for me.

1642.56.text:
And I took those opportunities and
went outside my comfort zone.

1648.78.text:
And followed my dreams and my passion 
of being an athlete.

1653.67.text:
And it's got me a gold medal and a 
World Championship medal.

1657.12.text:
It just goes to show that no matter 
how low you can get...

1659.91.text:
there's always some life left to live and it 
might just be on another route.
